DOC.HEAD: Publishers Ordered to Pay Damages for Showing AIDs Victim
DOC.TEXT: A court on Wednesday ordered two major publishers to pay $22,400 in damages for defaming Japan's first female AIDS victim by publishing her photograph in their weekly magazines after she died, one of the publishers said. The Osaka District Court ordered Kobunsha Co. and Shinchosha to pay the damages, according to a Kobunsha official. The official declined to discuss further details, including whether the companies would appeal to a higher court. Japan's first female AIDS patient died at the age of 29 on Jan. 20, 1987. The Health and Welfare Ministry, which did not identify the patient, listed sexual contact as the cause of her infection. Kyodo News Service quoted presiding Judge Yutaka Tahata as saying in his verdict that Shinchosha's Focus magazine and Kobunsha's Flash had defamed the woman by carrying her picture and ``groundless'' stories that invaded her privacy and harmed her parents' respect and affection for her. Kyodo said the parents had filed their libel suit in September 1987 demanding $140,000 in damages. As of April 10, 1989, 103 people in Japan had contracted AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, according to Health and Welfare Ministry figures. AIDS attacks the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to a wide variety of infections and cancers. It is most often transmitted through sexual contact, transfusions of tainted blood and the sharing of contaminated hypodermic needles by drug abusers.
